title: David Ball (footballer)
text:
David Michael Ball (born 14 December 1989) is an English professional <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who plays as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a> for <a href="Wellington%20Phoenix%20FC">Wellington Phoenix</a> in the <a href="A-League">A-League</a>.
He began his career at <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a>, but never made a first-team appearance despite being a star player in the club's <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.%20EDS%20and%20Academy">Reserve and Academy teams</a>. He started the 2010–11 season on loan at <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a>, before he was signed by <a href="Peterborough%20United%20F.C.">Peterborough United</a> in January 2011. Peterborough won promotion out of <a href="EFL%20League%20One">League One</a> via the <a href="2011%20Football%20League%20One%20play-off%20Final">play-offs in 2011</a>, though Ball returned to the division on loan at <a href="Rochdale%20A.F.C.">Rochdale</a> for the first half of the 2011–12 season. He was signed to <a href="Fleetwood%20Town%20F.C.">Fleetwood Town</a> in July 2012, and helped the club to win the <a href="2014%20Football%20League%20Two%20play-off%20Final">2014 League Two play-off final</a>. He scored 49 goals in 209 league and cup games in a five-year stay at Fleetwood, before moving on to <a href="Rotherham%20United%20F.C.">Rotherham United</a> in June 2017. He helped Rotherham to win the <a href="2018%20EFL%20League%20One%20play-off%20Final">2018 League One play-offs</a>, but left the club after spending most of the 2018–19 season on loan at <a href="Bradford%20City%20A.F.C.">Bradford City</a>.
Career.
Manchester City.
Ball spent his early childhood with Prestwich Marauders, before he joined the <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.%20EDS%20and%20Academy">youth system</a> at <a href="Manchester%20City%20F.C.">Manchester City</a> at the age of seven. He battled back from a foot injury at the end of his teenage years. A star of the youth and reserve sides he scored in the 2008 final of the <a href="FA%20Youth%20Cup">FA Youth Cup</a>, which City won, and was joint-fifth top-scorer in the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Premier%20Reserve%20League">2008–09 Premier Reserve League</a> and joint-second top-scorer in the <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Premier%20Reserve%20League">2009–10 Premier Reserve League</a>. He was named as City's Academy Player of the Month for December 2007 and Reserve team Player of the Month for February 2008.<ref name="jan/feb awards"></ref> He made it onto the first-team bench only once, though this was for the famous <a href="Manchester%20derby">Manchester derby</a> game on 20 September 2009 where City <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.%204%E2%80%933%20Manchester%20City%20F.C.%20%282009%29">lost 4–3</a> to <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> at <a href="Old%20Trafford">Old Trafford</a>.
He was loaned out to <a href="EFL%20League%20One">League One</a> club <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a> in July 2010 for six months, in order to gain first team experience. This came despite interest from other clubs. He made his <a href="English%20Football%20League">league</a> debut at the <a href="County%20Ground%20%28Swindon%29">County Ground</a> on 7 August 2010, in a 2–1 defeat to <a href="Brighton%20%26amp%3B%20Hove%20Albion%20F.C.">Brighton & Hove Albion</a>, but was <a href="substitute%20%28association%20football%29">replaced</a> by <a href="Alan%20O%27Brien">Alan O'Brien</a> after sixty minutes for tactical reasons. He was initially played out of position in <a href="Midfielder">midfield</a> by manager <a href="Danny%20Wilson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201960%29">Danny Wilson</a> and then spent time on the substitutes bench before taking an injured <a href="Charlie%20Austin">Charlie Austin</a>'s place up front in October. He scored his first senior goal on 5 October, as Swindon beat <a href="Torquay%20United%20F.C.">Torquay United</a> 2–0 in the <a href="EFL%20Trophy">Football League Trophy</a>. He scored a brace eleven days later in a 5–4 defeat at <a href="Peterborough%20United%20F.C.">Peterborough United</a>. He was then benched in favour of Charlie Austin and <a href="Vincent%20P%C3%A9ricard">Vincent Péricard</a>, returning to the <a href="City%20of%20Manchester%20Stadium">City of Manchester Stadium</a> in January after scoring a total of three goals in nine starts and 12 substitute appearances for Swindon.
Peterborough United.
Ball signed a -year deal for <a href="Darren%20Ferguson">Darren Ferguson</a>'s Peterborough United on 31 January 2011 after being bought for an undisclosed transfer fee. He scored five goals in 21 appearances for "Posh" in the second half of the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Peterborough%20United%20F.C.%20season">2010–11</a> season, and was a stoppage-time substitute for <a href="Lee%20Tomlin">Lee Tomlin</a> in the <a href="2011%20Football%20League%20One%20play-off%20Final">League One play-off final</a> as United secured promotion into the <a href="EFL%20Championship">Championship</a> with a 3–0 victory over <a href="Huddersfield%20Town%20A.F.C.">Huddersfield Town</a>.
He was partnered with Tomlin following the sale of <a href="Craig%20Mackail-Smith">Craig Mackail-Smith</a> to Brighton at the start of the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Peterborough%20United%20F.C.%20season">2011–12</a> season. However Ball returned to League One on loan at <a href="Rochdale%20A.F.C.">Rochdale</a> on 31 August after Peterborough signed <a href="Emile%20Sinclair">Emile Sinclair</a> from <a href="Macclesfield%20Town%20F.C.">Macclesfield Town</a>. He scored four goals in eight games for the "Dale", which led to him being recalled to <a href="London%20Road%20Stadium">London Road</a> on 10 October to compete with <a href="Paul%20Taylor%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201987%29">Paul Taylor</a> and Emile Sinclair for a starting place in the absence of <a href="Nicky%20Ajose">Nicky Ajose</a> (loaned out) and Lee Tomlin (injured). Ball made just five substitute appearances however, and returned to Rochdale on loan on 24 November. His second loan spell at Rochdale was not as successful as his first spell as he failed to find the net in seven games and manager <a href="Steve%20Eyre">Steve Eyre</a> was sacked. He was put on the transfer-list at Peterborough in April 2012.
Fleetwood Town.
On 23 July 2012, Ball signed for newly-promoted <a href="EFL%20League%20Two">League Two</a> side <a href="Fleetwood%20Town%20F.C.">Fleetwood Town</a> on a three-year deal. He started the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20Fleetwood%20Town%20F.C.%20season">2012–13</a> season playing out of position until manager <a href="Micky%20Mellon">Micky Mellon</a> was replaced by <a href="Graham%20Alexander">Graham Alexander</a> in December. He ended the campaign with nine goals in 38 games, before scoring 13 goals from 40 appearances in the <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20Fleetwood%20Town%20F.C.%20season">2013–14</a> season. Fleetwood won promotion out of League Two with a 1–0 victory over <a href="Burton%20Albion%20F.C.">Burton Albion</a> in the <a href="2014%20Football%20League%20Two%20play-off%20Final">2014 play-off final</a>. On 29 March 2015, he scored a goal that was a described as a "spectacular lob" and an "exquisite chip" to secure a 1–1 draw with <a href="Preston%20North%20End%20F.C.">Preston North End</a> at <a href="Highbury%20Stadium%20%28Fleetwood%29">Highbury Stadium</a>, which later saw him nominated for the <a href="FIFA%20Pusk%C3%A1s%20Award">FIFA Puskás Award</a>; this made him only the second Englishman to be nominated for the award, after <a href="Wayne%20Rooney">Wayne Rooney</a> in 2011. He scored eight goals in 30 League One games for the "Fishermen" during the <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20Fleetwood%20Town%20F.C.%20season">2014–15</a> campaign.
In August 2015, Ball signed a new two-year contract with Fleetwood. He was limited to five goals in 42 matches in the <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Fleetwood%20Town%20F.C.%20season">2015–16</a> season, before hitting a career-high 14 goals from 55 matches in the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Fleetwood%20Town%20F.C.%20season">2016–17</a> season. He left the "Trawlermen" after rejecting manager <a href="Uwe%20R%C3%B6sler">Uwe Rösler</a>'s new contract offer.
Rotherham United.
On 22 June 2017, Ball signed for <a href="Rotherham%20United%20F.C.">Rotherham United</a> on a two-year deal; he said he was persuaded to come to the <a href="New%20York%20Stadium">New York Stadium</a> after hearing manager <a href="Paul%20Warne">Paul Warne</a>'s ambitious plans. He scored his first goal for Rotherham in an EFL Trophy tie against Manchester City Under-23s on 15 August 2017. He finished the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Rotherham%20United%20F.C.%20season">2017–18</a> season with nine goals in 38 games for the "Millers" and helped the club to win promotion despite missing a penalty during the 2–1 extra-time win over <a href="Shrewsbury%20Town%20F.C.">Shrewsbury Town</a> in the <a href="2018%20EFL%20League%20One%20play-off%20Final">League One play-off final</a>.
On 3 September 2018, <a href="Bradford%20City%20A.F.C.">Bradford City</a> confirmed the signing of Ball until the end of the <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Bradford%20City%20A.F.C.%20season">2018–19</a> season, in a deal that was signed on the loan deadline of 31 August. The deal was confirmed just hours before manager <a href="Michael%20Collins%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201986%29">Michael Collins</a> was sacked. He scored his first goal for Bradford in an EFL Trophy tie against <a href="Barnsley%20F.C.">Barnsley</a> on 13 November. In December 2018 he was praised by City teammate <a href="Hope%20Akpan">Hope Akpan</a>, and in May 2019 he was credited by "Bantams" manager <a href="Gary%20Bowyer">Gary Bowyer</a> for helping <a href="Lewis%20O%27Brien%20%28footballer%29">Lewis O'Brien</a> to develop as a young player. On returning from his loan at <a href="Valley%20Parade">Valley Parade</a>, Ball was released by Rotherham at the end of his contract.
Wellington Phoenix.
On 12 July 2019, <a href="Wellington%20Phoenix%20FC">Wellington Phoenix</a> announced that Ball had signed a two-year contract with the club.
Honours.

Peterborough United
Fleetwood Town
Rotherham United
